post.body:
>>2Qlm+NnE

ZeroID is operated by the main developer of ZeroNet, @nofish. 
And ZeroVerse is ran by someone else, which provides a similar service, but exclusively using BitMessage

Every site can choose which certificates they accept, like this for the official ZeroBlog [a]:

 "user_contents": {
  "cert_signers": {
   "zeroid.bit": [ "1iD5ZQJMNXu43w1qLB8sfdHVKppVMduGz" ]
  },

So if you have a user certificate signed by "1iD5ZQJMNXu43w1qLB8sfdHVKppVMduGz" or ZeroID
you can add user data like a comment or vote on that website.

And this Nanasi text board accepts users from ZeroID, and a self-signed certificate [b]. 
And the part that defines which certificates are allowed to be signed by, looks like this:

 "user_contents": {
  "cert_signers": {
   "nanasi": [ "16PmAP6z2MCJX9jNjvMrteMfnqX4KeDRNT" ],
   "zeroid.bit": [ "1iD5ZQJMNXu43w1qLB8sfdHVKppVMduGz" ]
  },

So Nanasi text board accepts users with a ZeroID-signed certificate and Nanasi-signed (self-signed) certificate.

[a]: This is from [ZERONET]/data/1BLogC9LN4oPDcruNz3qo1ysa133E9AGg8/data/users/content.json
[b]: The private key to sign your user certificate is embedded into the application, 
so people can sign their own certificates without requiring a central certificate authority.

post.name: No name
post.body:
ZeroVerse is an alternative to ZeroID.

But it doesn't use a web server like ZeroID but you must send a BitMessage with ZeroVerse (ZeroID added support for BitMessage as well).

The keys posted here are public keys, Nanasi's private key
can be considered public because it is embedded into the application.

post.body: But ZeroVerse is centralized as well, there's a central party that signs your certificate.

post.name: No name
post.body:
But I think rate-limiting can and should be done at the site or peer level.
Because if someone already has 100 ZeroID-signed certificates and the site accepts 
ZeroID-signed certificates a site quickly can be spammed and the ZeroID certificate authority can't do anything to stop it.

>>WbTGIJwE
I'm thinking of creating a site where you can sign your own certificates.
And add some explanation on how to accept those certificates in your site. Plus a tutorial on how to create your own self-signed certificate "authority".

Now because almost all sites accept ZeroID and you can't really switch ZeroIDs easily, you can easily be tracked on ZeroNet, and thus be pretty quickly deanonymized.
